docs.title: Integration Framework
docs.text: This document outlines the process of integrating with Any SOAP-based services using Pydantic models. The solution automates the generation of Pydantic models from the WSDL file provided by Finacle, ensuring robust data validation, simplifying payload handling, and accelerating development.

docs.title: ** Important **
docs.text:
Generation of Pydantic models from the WSDL file.

  1. Go to the project folder, Open the script/_test_zeep_pydantic_class.py
  2. Replace with your WSDL URL
  3. Use the uv command to execute the script.
cd Integration-Framework
open _test_zeep_pydantic_class.py
url = "http://www.dneonline.com/calculator.asmx?wsdl"
uv run python3 scripts/_test_zeep_pydantic_class.py

docs.title: Objective
docs.text:
1. Automate the generation of Pydantic models from Finacle's WSDL file.
  2. Validate request and response payloads using Pydantic's data validation capabilities.
  3. Rapidly implement Finacle services by reusing generated models.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
1. Fetch the WSDL file from the Finacle SOAP endpoint.
  2. Dynamically generate Pydantic models for all SOAP operations (input and output).
  3. Use the generated models to validate payloads and interact with Finacle services.
  4. Copy the standalone models into caml_types/input_entity_types.py for reuse across the system.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
1. Type Safety: Ensures data integrity by validating request and response payloads.
  2. Rapid Development: Reduces manual effort by automating model generation.
  3. Reusability: Generated models can be reused across multiple services.
  4. Standardization: Provides a consistent way to handle Finacle SOAP APIs.

docs.title: Fetching the WSDL File
docs.text: The WSDL file is fetched from the Finacle SOAP endpoint. This file describes the available SOAP operations, their input parameters, and output structures.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
from zeep import Client
# Finacle SOAP endpoint
wsdl_url = "https://finacle-endpoint.com/service?wsdl"
client = Client(wsdl_url)

docs.title: Generating Pydantic Models
docs.text: Using the WSDL file, we dynamically generate Pydantic models for each SOAP operation. These models represent the input and output structures of the operations.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field, create_model
from typing import Dict, Type

# Dictionary to store generated models
pydantic_models: Dict[str, Type[BaseModel]] = {}

# Function to map SOAP types to Python types
def map_soap_type_to_python_type(soap_type):
    if soap_type == "xsd:string":
        return str
    elif soap_type == "xsd:int":
        return int
    elif soap_type == "xsd:float":
        return float
    elif soap_type == "xsd:boolean":
        return bool
    elif soap_type == "xsd:dateTime":
        return str
    else:
        return str  # Default to string for unknown types

# Function to create Pydantic models
def create_pydantic_model(name: str, elements: Dict[str, str]) -> Type[BaseModel]:
    annotations = {
        element: (map_soap_type_to_python_type(type_), Field(..., description=f"Field {element}"))
        for element, type_ in elements.items()
    }
    return create_model(name, **annotations)

# Iterate over SOAP operations and generate models
for service in client.wsdl.services.values():
    for port in service.ports.values():
        operations = port.binding._operations
        for operation_name, operation in operations.items():
            # Generate input model
            input_elements = {element[0]: element[1].type for element in operation.input.body.type.elements}
            input_model = create_pydantic_model(f"{operation_name}Input", input_elements)
            pydantic_models[f"{operation_name}Input"] = input_model

            # Generate output model
            output_elements = {element[0]: element[1].type for element in operation.output.body.type.elements}
            output_model = create_pydantic_model(f"{operation_name}Output", output_elements)
            pydantic_models[f"{operation_name}Output"] = output_model

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
# Example payload for the "Add" operation
payload = {
    "intA": 10,
    "intB": 20
}
# Call the Finacle service
response = call_finacle_service("Add", payload)
print("Response:", response)

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
class AddInput(BaseModel):
    intA: int
    intB: int

class AddOutput(BaseModel):
    AddResult: int

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
1. Automation:
    • Dynamically generates Pydantic models from the WSDL file.
    • Reduces manual effort and ensures consistency.
  2. Validation:
    • Validates request and response payloads using Pydantic.
    • Ensures data integrity and type safety.
  3. Reusability:
    • Generated models are stored in caml_types/input_entity_types.py for reuse.
    • Promotes a standardized approach to handling Finacle services.
  4. Scalability:
    • Can handle multiple Finacle services and operations.
    • Easily extendable to support additional SOAP APIs.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: This solution provides a robust and efficient way to integrate with Finacle's SOAP services. By automating the generation of Pydantic models and validating payloads, it accelerates development, ensures data integrity, and promotes reusability across the system. This approach is particularly beneficial for rapidly implementing Finacle services while maintaining high standards of code quality and reliability.

docs.title: Email
docs.text:
Official Documentation: https://docs.python.org/3/library/smtplib.html

The smtplib module defines an SMTP client session object that can be used to send mail to any internet machine with an SMTP or ESMTP listener daemon. For details of SMTP and ESMTP operation, consult RFC 821 (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) and RFC 1869 (SMTP Service Extensions).

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: The reason for this is that smtplib is inbuilt to Python. Therefore, it is installed initially with the Python installation.

docs.title: Config.toml
docs.text:
[email]
from_email = "abcd@digid.ai"
password = "abc"
smtp_server =  "smtp.gmail.com"
smtp_port = 587
use_tls = "True"

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: just run api email

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
[*] loading from dummy toml file
input_data :: to_email='ezhil@tocode.ai'
server :  <smtplib.SMTP object at 0x105227ce0>
Email sent successfully!
result :  True

docs.title: Input Types
docs.text:
class EmailEntityInput(BaseModel):
    to_email: str

Modify the EmailEntityInput class in caml_types/input_entity_types.py based on the requirement change.

docs.title: Dummy test (Inputdata.toml)
docs.text:
[email]
to_email = "ezhil@tocode.ai"

docs.title: Dummy data
docs.text:
just run api email #it will take the default values from the just
just run api email config.toml 0 dummy inputdata.toml


# with paramater
just run api config_channel_type="email" config_file_path="config.toml" config_entry_name="0" config_source_data="dummy"

docs.title: Database  data
docs.text:
just run api email database 12314 0 config.toml inputdata.toml

# with paramater
just run api config_channel_type="email" config_source_data="database" application_id="12314" config_entry_name="0"  --config_file_path="config.toml" --config_source_file="/Applications/toCode/Integration-Framework/inputdata.toml"

docs.title: Finacle
docs.text:
Official Documentation: <>

Finacle is an industry-leading digital banking solution suite from EdgeVerve Systems, a wholly owned subsidiary of Infosys, designed to help financial institutions drive digital transformation and enhance customer experiences.

docs.title: Config.toml
docs.text:
[finacle.dedupcheckcif]
finacle_url = "http://bank_url.com/fiwebservice/services/FIPWebService"
input_file_path = "finacle/DedupCheckCIF.xml"
mime_type = "text"

just run api config_channel_type="finacle" config_file_path="config.toml" config_entry_name="dedupcheckcif" config_source_data="dummy"

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Integration-Framework is a modular and extensible system designed to facilitate seamless communication between various banking and enterprise services. It includes API wrappers, data parsers, configuration management, and testing utilities to ensure smooth integration and execution of financial and authentication-related workflows.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
Integration-Framework/
├── _test_api.py
├── api/
│   ├── api_wrapper.py
│   ├── email_wrapper.py
│   ├── finacle_wrapper.py
│   ├── ldap_wrapper.py
│   └── sms_wrapper.py
├── caml_types/
│   ├── api_types.py
│   ├── config_types.py
│   ├── input_entity_types.py
│   ├── request_config_types.py
│   └── response_entity_types.py
├── config.toml
├── finacle/
│   ├── CIFAdd.xml
│   ├── DedupCheckCIF.xml
│   ├── SBAActAdd.xml
│   ├── SVSSignatureAdd.xml
│   └── VerifyCIF.xml
├── finacle_helper/
│   ├── cif_add_parser.py
│   ├── dup_check_parser.py
│   └── generic_reponse_parser.py
├── finacle_response/
│   ├── cif-add-resp-error.txt
│   └── dup-check-cif-res.txt
├── input.toml
├── inputdata.toml
├── Integration-Framework.code-workspace
├── Justfile
├── load_data.py
├── mybank.py
├── pyproject.toml
├── README.md
├── scripts/
│   ├── _test_aml_ind.py
│   ├── _test_api.py
│   ├── _test_digio.py
│   ├── _test_zeep.py
│   ├── _test_zeep_pydantic_class.py
│   ├── aml2.py
│   ├── input.toml
│   └── pipe-line_finacle_test.py
├── task_helper/
│   ├── api_clients.py
│   ├── api_factory.py
│   └── function_runner_mixin.py
├── tests/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   ├── test_cif_add.py
│   ├── test_dup_check.py
│   ├── test_email.py
│   ├── test_ldap.py
│   ├── test_sba_add.py
│   ├── test_sms.py
│   └── test_svs_add.py
├── utils/
│   ├── interpolation_utils.py
│   └── utils.py
└── uv.lock

docs.title: API Wrappers (api/)
docs.text:
Contains Python modules that wrap external services for ease of use:

api_wrapper.py – General API wrapper for handling requests.

email_wrapper.py – Manages email-based interactions.

finacle_wrapper.py – Interfaces with the Finacle Core Banking System.

ldap_wrapper.py – Handles LDAP authentication and user management.

sms_wrapper.py – Sends and receives SMS messages.

docs.title: CAML Types (caml_types/)
docs.text:
Defines structured types for handling API requests and responses:

api_types.py – Defines API-related data structures.

config_types.py – Holds configuration-related types.

input_entity_types.py – Manages input entities for various services.

request_config_types.py – Specifies request configurations.

response_entity_types.py – Defines expected API response formats.

docs.title: Finacle XML Requests (finacle/)
docs.text:
Includes pre-defined XML templates for Finacle banking operations:

CIFAdd.xml – Adds a Customer Information File (CIF).

DedupCheckCIF.xml – Performs duplicate checks on CIFs.

SBAActAdd.xml – Adds Savings Bank Accounts (SBA).

SVSSignatureAdd.xml – Stores signature verification data.

VerifyCIF.xml – Validates customer CIF details.

docs.title: Finacle Response Parsers (finacle_helper/)
docs.text:
Handles the processing of Finacle API responses:

cif_add_parser.py – Parses responses for CIF Add operations.

dup_check_parser.py – Parses duplicate check results.

generic_response_parser.py – General-purpose response parser.

docs.title: Configuration & Input Files
docs.text:
config.toml – Holds framework-wide configuration settings.

input.toml & inputdata.toml – Provide sample input data.

docs.title: Scripts (scripts/)
docs.text:
Contains test scripts and utilities for interacting with APIs:

_test_api.py – Tests general API functionality.

_test_aml_ind.py – Tests Anti-Money Laundering (AML) functions.

_test_digio.py – Validates integration with Digio services.

_test_zeep.py – Tests Zeep SOAP-based API clients.

pipe-line_finacle_test.py – Automates Finacle API testing.

docs.title: Task Helper (task_helper/)
docs.text:
api_clients.py – Manages API clients.

api_factory.py – Factory pattern for creating API instances.

function_runner_mixin.py – Provides function execution utilities.

docs.title: Testing (tests/)
docs.text:
Includes unit tests for various components:

test_cif_add.py – Tests CIF Add operation.

test_dup_check.py – Tests duplicate CIF check.

test_email.py – Tests email functionality.

test_ldap.py – Validates LDAP authentication.

test_sba_add.py – Tests Savings Bank Account (SBA) addition.

test_sms.py – Tests SMS service interactions.

test_svs_add.py – Tests SVS signature addition.

docs.title: Utilities (utils/)
docs.text:
interpolation_utils.py – Manages dynamic value interpolation.

utils.py – Contains general utility functions.

docs.title: Workspace & Dependencies
docs.text:
Integration-Framework.code-workspace – VS Code workspace settings.

Justfile – Task automation script (similar to Makefile).

pyproject.toml – Python project dependencies and configuration.

uv.lock – Dependency lockfile for dependency management.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
✅ API Wrappers – Seamless integration with Finacle, LDAP, and SMS services.
✅ XML-Based Requests – Predefined Finacle XML request templates.
✅ Response Parsers – Efficient handling of Finacle responses.
✅ Configuration-Driven – Uses TOML files for easy customization.
✅ Testing Suite – Comprehensive unit tests for robust API validation.
✅ Task Automation – Supports Justfile for easy task execution.

docs.title: Just: A Command Runner for Projects
docs.text:
1. Github Documentation: https://github.com/casey/just
  2. Official Documentation: https://just.systems/man/en/

Just is a handy command runner that allows you to save and run project-specific commands from a Justfile. It is similar to make but designed to be simpler and more modern, with a focus on readability and ease of use.

docs.title: Why Use Just?
docs.text:
1. Simplicity: Easier to read and write than Makefile.
  2. Portability: Works on macOS, Linux, and Windows.
  3. Modern Features: Supports variables, dependencies, and command-line arguments.
  4. Project-Specific: Keeps all your project commands in one place.

docs.title: Installation Commands: Just
docs.text:
check this : https://github.com/casey/just?tab=readme-ov-file#cross-platform

Install Just using a package manager:

# Install Just on macOS using Homebrew
brew install just

# Install Just on Linux using Cargo (Rust's package manager)
cargo install just

# Install Just on Windows using Scoop
scoop install just

docs.title: Command Stuctutre
docs.text:
just run api <config_channel_type>
                <config_source_data>
                <application_id> 
                <config_entry_name>
                <config_file_path>
                <config_source_file>

docs.title: Sets the communication channel to email.
docs.text:
- config_channel_type
    - email
    - ldap
    - sms
    - finacle

docs.title: Configures the API to fetch data from the database.
docs.text:
- config_source_data
    - database
    - dummy

docs.title: Identifies the specific application instance
docs.text:
- application_id="12314"

# if config_source_data is database, will get data from database

docs.title: Defines the entry configuration
docs.text:
- config_entry_name="0" # default will be 0

# if config_channel_type is fiancle, choose the finacle service

- finacle
    - dedupcheckcif
    - cifadd
    - verifycif
    - sbaactadd
    - svssignatureadd
  1. dedupcheckcif - Checks for duplicate customer records before CIF creation to prevent redundancy.
  2. cifadd - Creates a new Customer Information File (CIF) in the banking system.
  3. verifycif - Validates and authenticates existing customer information in Finacle.
  4. sbaactadd - Opens a new Savings Bank Account linked to an existing CIF.
  5. svssignatureadd - Registers customer signatures for account verification purposes.

docs.title: Environment-Specific Configuration
docs.text: The configuration files (config.toml and inputdata.toml) are used to manage different environments:

docs.title: SIT (System Integration Testing)
docs.text: Config file contains test data and lower-level configurations.

docs.title: UAT (User Acceptance Testing)
docs.text: Uses pre-production configurations for validation by end users.

docs.title: PROD (Production)
docs.text: Uses live configurations with actual data sources.

docs.title: Specifies the main configuration file used.
docs.text: --config_file_path="config.toml"

docs.title: Points to the input data source for integration.
docs.text:
--config_source_file="/Applications/toCode/Integration-Framework/inputdata.toml"
Basic Commands :: Examples : (Optional)

docs.title: Verify Installation:
docs.text: just --version

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
Create a Justfile

A Justfile is a text file where you define your commands (called "recipes"). Here's an example:

# Justfile

# Default recipe (runs when you type `just`)
default:
    echo "Hello, World!"

# Run tests
test:
    cargo test

# Start the development server
start:
    python -m http.server 8000

# Clean build artifacts
clean:
    rm -rf build/

docs.title: Frequently Used CLI Commands
docs.text:
# Run the default recipe
just

# Run a specific recipe
just <recipe-name>

# List all available recipes
just --list

# Dry run: Print commands without executing them
just --dry-run <recipe-name>

# Edit the Justfile
just --edit

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
You can define variables in your Justfile:

# Define a variable
PORT := 8000

start:
    echo "Starting server on port {{PORT}}"
    python -m http.server {{PORT}}

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
Recipes can depend on other recipes:

build:
    echo "Building..."
    touch build/output.txt

deploy: build
    echo "Deploying..."
    cp build/output.txt /var/www/

docs.title: Command-Line Arguments
docs.text:
Pass arguments to recipes:

greet NAME:
    echo "Hello, {{NAME}}!"

Run it with:

just greet Alice

docs.title: Example Justfile for a Python Project
docs.text:
# Justfile for a Python project

# Default recipe
default:
    just --list

# Install dependencies
install:
    pip install -r requirements.txt

# Run tests
test:
    pytest

# Format code
format:
    black .
    isort .

# Lint code
lint:
    flake8 .
    mypy .

# Clean up
clean:
    rm -rf __pycache__/
    rm -rf .mypy_cache/

docs.title: LDAP
docs.text:
Official Documentation: https://ldap3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/connection.html

ldap3 is a strictly RFC 4510 conforming LDAP v3 pure Python client library. The whole ldap3 library has been written from scratch and the same codebase works with Python 2, Python 3, PyPy and PyPy3 on any system where it can gain access to the network via Python and its Standard Library.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: uv add ldap3

docs.title: Config.toml
docs.text:
[ldap]
host = "ldap://abc.co.ug"
base_dn = "DC=abc, DC=co, DC=ug"
search_dn = "CN=abc, OU=Head Office, OU=Security Groups, OU=BAC Groups, DC=abc, DC=co, DC=ug"
username = "abc"
password = "asdfasdfasdfsadfad="

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: just run api ldap

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
[*] loading from dummy toml file
input_data :: username='abc' password='123123123'
result :  (False, 'LDAP Authentication Success')

docs.title: Libraries
docs.text:
This project uses the following tools and libraries:

Category Tool Description Documentation Python Version Management pyenv Manage and switch between multiple Python versions. pyenv GitHub Python Packaging uv Fast Python package installer and dependency resolver. uv Docs [Optional] poetry Dependency management and packaging tool for Python projects. Poetry Docs Project Documentation mkDocs Static site generator for project documentation using Markdown. MkDocs Project-Specific Commands just Command runner for defining and executing project-specific tasks. Just Docs Python Linter & Formatter ruff Extremely fast Python linter and code formatter. Ruff Docs Python Testing Framework pytest Powerful and flexible testing framework for Python. pytest Docs Python Data Validation Pydantic Data validation and settings management using Python type annotations. Pydantic Docs Python SOAP Client Zeep Modern SOAP client for interacting with SOAP-based web services. Zeep Docs

docs.title: Installation Commands
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

# Install pyenv (Python Version Management)
echo "Installing pyenv..."
curl https://pyenv.run | bash
echo 'export PYENV_ROOT="$HOME/.pyenv"' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'command -v pyenv >/dev/null || export PATH="$PYENV_ROOT/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'eval "$(pyenv init -)"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

# Install Python (latest stable version) using pyenv
echo "Installing Python via pyenv..."
pyenv install 3.11.5  # Replace with the desired version
pyenv global 3.11.5

# Install Just (Project-specific commands)
echo "Installing Just..."
curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://just.systems/install.sh | bash -s -- --to ~/.local/bin

docs.title: Commands : Installation UV Library
docs.text:
# Install uv (Python package installer)
echo "Installing uv..."
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Poetry Installation Commands (if not using UV packages) [Optional]
docs.text:
# Install Poetry (Python dependency management)
echo "Installing Poetry..."
curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: UV Installation Commands
docs.text:
# Install MkDocs (Project documentation)
echo "Installing MkDocs..."
uv add mkdocs

# Install Ruff (Python linter and formatter)
echo "Installing Ruff..."
uv add ruff

# Install pytest (Python testing framework)
echo "Installing pytest..."
uv add pytest

# Install Pydantic (Python data validation library)
echo "Installing Pydantic..."
uv add pydantic

# Install Zeep (Python SOAP client)
echo "Installing Zeep..."
uv add zeep

echo "All dependencies installed successfully!"

docs.title: PIP Installation Commands (if not using UV packages) [Optional]
docs.text:
# Install MkDocs (Project documentation)
echo "Installing MkDocs..."
pip install mkdocs

# Install Ruff (Python linter and formatter)
echo "Installing Ruff..."
pip install ruff

# Install pytest (Python testing framework)
echo "Installing pytest..."
pip install pytest

# Install Pydantic (Python data validation library)
echo "Installing Pydantic..."
pip install pydantic

# Install Zeep (Python SOAP client)
echo "Installing Zeep..."
pip install zeep

echo "All dependencies installed successfully!"

docs.title: Python Version Management (pyenv)
docs.text:
Offical Documentation : https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv

pyenv: A tool to easily switch between multiple versions of Python. It helps manage different Python versions for different projects, ensuring compatibility.

docs.title: Installation Commands : Pyenv Library (Python Version Management)
docs.text:
echo "Installing pyenv..."
curl https://pyenv.run | bash
echo 'export PYENV_ROOT="$HOME/.pyenv"' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'command -v pyenv >/dev/null || export PATH="$PYENV_ROOT/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
echo 'eval "$(pyenv init -)"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Frequently Using  Cli Commands
docs.text:
# pyenv accepts a switch to the install command to list available versions: --list, or -l
pyenv install -l

# Install a specific Python version.
pyenv install <version>

# Set the global Python version.
pyenv global <version>

# Set the Python version for the current project.
pyenv local <version>

# List all installed Python versions.
pyenv <versions>

# Show the current Python version(s) and its origin
pyenv <version>

docs.title: Pyenv commands
docs.text:
Usage: pyenv <command> [<args>]

Some useful pyenv commands are:
--version   Display the version of pyenv
commands    List all available pyenv commands
exec        Run an executable with the selected Python version
global      Set or show the global Python version(s)
help        Display help for a command
hooks       List hook scripts for a given pyenv command
init        Configure the shell environment for pyenv
install     Install a Python version using python-build
latest      Print the latest installed or known version with the given prefix
local       Set or show the local application-specific Python version(s)
prefix      Display prefixes for Python versions
rehash      Rehash pyenv shims (run this after installing executables)
root        Display the root directory where versions and shims are kept
shell       Set or show the shell-specific Python version
shims       List existing pyenv shims
uninstall   Uninstall Python versions
version     Show the current Python version(s) and its origin
version-file   Detect the file that sets the current pyenv version
version-name   Show the current Python version
version-origin   Explain how the current Python version is set
versions    List all Python versions available to pyenv
whence      List all Python versions that contain the given executable
which       Display the full path to an executable

docs.title: Testing framework
docs.text:
1. Official Documentation: https://docs.pytest.org/en/stable/

Pytest is a Python testing framework that originated from the PyPy project. It can be used to write various types of software tests, including unit tests, integration tests, end-to-end tests, and functional tests. Its features include parametrized testing, fixtures, and assert re-writing.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: uv add pytest --dev

docs.title: Version
docs.text: uv run pytest --version

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: just run test <folder/filepath.py>

docs.title: SMS
docs.text: just run test tests/test_sms.py

docs.title: LDAP
docs.text: just run test tests/test_ldap.py

docs.title: Email
docs.text: just run test tests/test_email.py

docs.title: CIF Add
docs.text: just run test tests/test_cif_add.py

docs.title: Verify Add
docs.text: just run test tests/test_cif_add.py

docs.title: Dup Add
docs.text: just run test tests/test_dup_check.py

docs.title: SBA Add
docs.text: just run test tests/test_sba_add.py

docs.title: SVS Add
docs.text: just run test tests/test_svs_add.py

docs.title: Ruff
docs.text:
Official Documentation: https://github.com/charliermarsh/ruff

An Extremely Fast Python Linter

Ruff is a blazingly fast Python linter and code formatter, written in Rust. It aims to be a drop-in replacement for tools like Flake8, isort, and Black, providing a unified and efficient way to lint and format Python code.

docs.title: Why Use Ruff?
docs.text:
1. Speed: Ruff is significantly faster than traditional Python linters.
  2. Unified Tool: Combines linting and formatting in a single tool.
  3. Rust-Powered: Written in Rust for performance and reliability.
  4. Compatibility: Works seamlessly with existing tools like Flake8, isort, and Black.

docs.title: Installation Commands: Ruff
docs.text:
# Install Ruff using pip
pip install ruff

# Alternatively, install Ruff using pipx for isolated environments
pipx install ruff

docs.title: Frequently Used CLI Commands
docs.text:
# Lint all Python files in the current directory and subdirectories
ruff check .

# Lint a specific file or directory
ruff check path/to/file_or_directory

# Automatically fix linting errors (where possible)
ruff check --fix .

# Format Python files (similar to Black)
ruff format .

# Show all available linting rules
ruff rule

# Ignore specific linting rules
ruff check --ignore E501,E203 .

# Generate a configuration file (`.ruff.toml`)
ruff generate-config

docs.title: Ruff Commands
docs.text:
Usage: ruff <command> [<args>]

Some useful Ruff commands are:
check       Lint Python files
format      Format Python files
rule        Show information about a specific linting rule
generate-config   Generate a configuration file
help        Display help for a command

docs.title: Example .ruff.toml Configuration File
docs.text:
# Example Ruff configuration file
[tool.ruff]
# Enable specific linting rules
select = ["E", "F", "W", "I", "B"]

# Ignore specific linting rules
ignore = ["E501"]

# Set the maximum line length
line-length = 88

# Enable automatic fixes
fix = true

docs.title: Integrating Ruff with Pre-commit
docs.text:
Add Ruff to your .pre-commit-config.yaml file:

repos:
- repo: https://github.com/charliermarsh/ruff-pre-commit
    rev: v0.0.280  # Replace with the latest version
    hooks:
    - id: ruff
        args: [--fix]

docs.title: SMS
docs.text: Official Documentation: https://www.python-httpx.org/

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
config.toml

The config.toml file contains the necessary configuration for the SMS API. Update the following fields based on your requirements:

docs.title: Config.toml
docs.text:
[sms]
url = "http://acbc.ai/api/processrequestV2"
username =  "abc"
password = "GtWD7dP99R7Htv5wE6P2RqeWsdfsdf"
api_key =   "abc"
security_key = "abc"

docs.title: Input Types
docs.text:
class SMSEntityInput(BaseModel):
    phone_number: str

Modify the SMSEntityInput class in caml_types/input_entity_types.py based on the requirement change.

docs.title: Dummy test (Inputdata.toml)
docs.text:
[sms]
phone_number = "8489520000"

docs.title: Dummy data
docs.text:
just run api sms #it will take the default values from the just
just run api sms config.toml 0 dummy inputdata.toml


# with paramater
just run api config_channel_type="sms" config_file_path="config.toml" config_entry_name="0" config_source_data="dummy"

docs.title: Database  data
docs.text:
just run api sms config.toml 0 database 12314

# with paramater
just run api config_channel_type="sms" application_id=12314 config_file_path="config.toml"  config_source_data="database"  config_source_file="inputdata.toml"

docs.title: Dependency Management (UV)
docs.text:
Offical Documentation : https://docs.astral.sh/uv/

Python packaging and dependency management

docs.title: Installation Commands : UV Library
docs.text:
# Install uv (Python package installer)
echo "Installing uv..."
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Frequently Using  Cli Commands
docs.text:
# add library
uv add <package_name>
# eg :: uv add pandas

# remove library
uv remove <package_name>

# Synchronize dependencies.
uv sync

# Set the Python version for the current project.
uv run python3 <file_name.py>
uv run
    - mkdocs
    - pytest
    - python
    - python3
    - python3.12
    - ruff

# running tools without installation
uvx <command>

docs.title: UV commands
docs.text:
An extremely fast Python package manager.

Usage: uv [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

Commands:
run      Run a command or script
init     Create a new project
add      Add dependencies to the project
remove   Remove dependencies from the project
sync     Update the project's environment
lock     Update the project's lockfile
export   Export the project's lockfile to an alternate format
tree     Display the project's dependency tree
tool     Run and install commands provided by Python packages
python   Manage Python versions and installations
pip      Manage Python packages with a pip-compatible interface
venv     Create a virtual environment
build    Build Python packages into source distributions and wheels
publish  Upload distributions to an index
cache    Manage uv's cache
self     Manage the uv executable
version  Display uv's version
help     Display documentation for a command

Cache options:
-n, --no-cache               Avoid reading from or writing to the cache, instead using a temporary directory for the
                            duration of the operation [env: UV_NO_CACHE=]
    --cache-dir <CACHE_DIR>  Path to the cache directory [env: UV_CACHE_DIR=]

Python options:
    --python-preference <PYTHON_PREFERENCE>  Whether to prefer uv-managed or system Python installations [env:
                                            UV_PYTHON_PREFERENCE=] [possible values: only-managed, managed, system,
                                            only-system]
    --no-python-downloads                    Disable automatic downloads of Python. [env: "UV_PYTHON_DOWNLOADS=never"]

Global options:
-q, --quiet
        Do not print any output
-v, --verbose...
        Use verbose output
    --color <COLOR_CHOICE>
        Control colors in output [default: auto] [possible values: auto, always, never]
    --native-tls
        Whether to load TLS certificates from the platform's native certificate store [env: UV_NATIVE_TLS=]
    --offline
        Disable network access
    --allow-insecure-host <ALLOW_INSECURE_HOST>
        Allow insecure connections to a host [env: UV_INSECURE_HOST=]
    --no-progress
        Hide all progress outputs [env: UV_NO_PROGRESS=]
    --directory <DIRECTORY>
        Change to the given directory prior to running the command
    --project <PROJECT>
        Run the command within the given project directory
    --config-file <CONFIG_FILE>
        The path to a `uv.toml` file to use for configuration [env: UV_CONFIG_FILE=]
    --no-config
        Avoid discovering configuration files (`pyproject.toml`, `uv.toml`) [env: UV_NO_CONFIG=]
-h, --help
        Display the concise help for this command
-V, --version
        Display the uv version

Use `uv help` for more details.
